messages.subject: RE: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Greek Mythology ideas
messages.messageBody:
<<Yeah, this interest in Greek mythology actually started with an interest
in monsters and monster movies, which led to mythological craetures, which
has now led to mythology and Greek gods and godesses. >>>

So obviously the Ray Harryhausen masterpiece "Jason and the Argonauts" is a
huge favorite, right?

Robyn L. Coburn

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Greek Mythology ideas
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 6/11/2004 10:38:16 AM Eastern Daylight Time, ... Yeah, this interest in Greek mythology actually started with an interest in monsters and
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 6/11/2004 10:38:16 AM Eastern Daylight Time,
Wishbone@... writes:

> The only thing I can think of is Disney's Hercules.
> >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
> Yup. Completely wrong retelling but it sparked an interest in greek myths
> for my daughter and we spent last summer reading them. It's also meant that a
> little toy of Fluffy from Harry Potter has been named Cerebus and it also led
> to a brief interest in the solar system.
>

Yeah, this interest in Greek mythology actually started with an interest in
monsters and monster movies, which led to mythological craetures, which has now
led to mythology and Greek gods and godesses. There's a great Greek mythology
website for kids called Winged Sandals :
http://www.abc.net.au/arts/wingedsandals that my son loves too.
Amy Kagey
Usborne Books in Ohio
www.ubah.com/z0939




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Re: Greek Mythology ideas
messages.msgSnippet: Tara writes: The only thing I can think of is Disney s Hercules. ... Yup. Completely wrong retelling but it sparked an interest in greek myths for my daughter
messages.messageBody:
Tara writes:

The only thing I can think of is Disney's Hercules.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
Yup. Completely wrong retelling but it sparked an interest in greek myths for my daughter and we spent last summer reading them. It's also meant that a little toy of Fluffy from Harry Potter has been named Cerebus and it also led to a brief interest in the solar system.
Disney movies may suck for the most part in my mind ( I DID like Hercules though) but they prove the point that kids will take what they need and learn unexpected things from even the worst, most inaccurate sources. '6 Million Years BC' went a long way to proving that for me too though. Catherine loved that one.

Dawn (in NS)






[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Greek Mythology ideas
messages.msgSnippet: My dd (6) is also really into mythology and ancient civilizations. Two computer games she *loves* (along with dh!) are Ages of Empire and Ages of Mythology.
messages.messageBody:
My dd (6) is also really into mythology and ancient civilizations. Two
computer games she *loves* (along with dh!) are Ages of Empire and Ages of
Mythology. There a bit advanced, but dh is a pretty patient coach, and she
can play a scenario pretty independently now.

--Danielle

http://www.danielleconger.com/Homeschool/Welcomehome.html

messages.subject: Re: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Greek Mythology ideas
messages.msgSnippet: There are some tapes we ve listened to .....oh my, what is the name of them? I think there is at least one that was by either Jim Weiss (my first guess) or
messages.messageBody:
There are some tapes we've listened to .....oh my, what is the name of them?
I think there is at least one that was by either Jim Weiss (my first guess) or Odds Bodkin.
Odds is our favorite storyteller, but I'm pretty sure Jim did the greek myth tape.
We found them at our library.

Ann


----- Original Message -----
From: amycats2@...
To: UnschoolingDiscussion@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, June 10, 2004 11:23 AM
Subject: [UnschoolingDiscussion] Greek Mythology ideas


Hi,
Loking for resources for my 6.5yo son who is really into Greek mythology
right now. We have read the D'Auliere's book and Marcia William's Greek Myths
for Young Children which he LOVED (the cartoon strip style really appealed to
him.) I'm thinking that he might like to watch some videos, but he would prefer
something animated. Thanks for any suggestions!

Amy Kagey
Usborne Books in Ohio
www.ubah.com/z0939
